title: Wexford Festival Opera 2023 – your complete guide to everything taking place
body_text:
Wexford Festival Opera 2023 – your complete guide to everything taking place
From main stage operas, pop-up recitals, art exhibitions, Spiegeltent Festival and Jazz at Johnstown, there is something for everybody in Wexford this month
There is simply no better place to be in Ireland in October than Wexford, when the town becomes a hive of cultural activity to celebrate the annual Wexford Festival Opera. Now in its 72nd year, Wexford Festival Opera continues to amaze and delight in equal measure, when operatic performers from all over the world convene at the National Opera House for two weeks of world-class opera.
But of course, the great thing about Wexford Festival Opera is that it about so much more than opera. From lunchtime recitals to pop-up performances, lectures to tours, there is something for everyone during Wexford Festival Opera.
Add in Wexford Arts Festival, countless art exhibitions and the hugely successful Spiegeltent Festival and you have a cultural concoction of events that is unmatched anywhere in Ireland.
Below is a guide to everything that is happening throughout the next two weeks in Wexford:
Friday October 20
Outspoken
7.30 p.m. Red Books, St Peter’s Square
Outspoken is Wexford’s monthly spoken-word open-mic. Having started in 2022, it is hosted once a month by ‘The Wexeditors’ Deirdre McGarry and Álanna Hammel. The event has hosted much-loved local poets like Margaret Galvin, Anne Cousins, Paul Hennessy, Sinead O’Reilly, Ronán P. Berry, Éire Ní Fhaoláin, and many more. Rather than having a special guest, this festival session of Outspoken is an extended open-mic. What makes this one special? Dress code? Outrageously operatic.
Jazz at Johnstown: Cormac Kenevey &Trio
8 p.m. Johnstown Castle
In 2006, Cormac Kenevey funded and recorded his first album This Is Living – a collaboration with the exceptionally talented Dublin stalwart Phil Ware and his Trio whichwas quickly picked up and released by Alan Bates at the CANDID record label in London(home to Stacey Kent and Jamie Cullum). Thus began a career as a jazz singer with astring of critically acclaimed national and international appearances. His secondalbum The Art of Dreaming confirmed his place on the international jazz scene. His tourdates have included locations in London (Ronnie Scott’s, Pizza Express Dean St), aroundEurope, and as far afield Abu Dhabi and Mexico.
Tulua
8 p.m. Wexford Arts Centre
TULUA are a traditional Irish fusion band hailing from the southeast of Ireland. Meaning ‘Becoming More‘, TULUA have been deeply exploring and sharing their music which has achieved them national and international success. Since their EP release in 2020 they have played around the world, at festivals such as Milwaukee Irish Fest, La Crosse Irish Fest, Temple Bar Tradfest, Kilkenny Tradfest, Phil Murphy Weekend, and supporting renown acts such as Atlantic Arc, Fergal Scahill and Ryan Molloy, Cormac Begley, and many more, whilst also exclusively performing to their sold out concerts at the National Opera House.
Saturday October 21
Stanley McDonald Talk
11 a.m. Johnstown Castle
Author of “Johnstown Castle Society Sport and Sedition” Stanley McDonald will be discussing his book and research. It mentions the upstairs and downstairs lifestyle and the daily life in Johnstown Castle Estate from 1830’s onwards. There are stories of intrigue, loyalty and treachery, with discussion about cricket, gaelic football and hurling.
Launch of Making Waves
2.30 p.m. Wexford Library
Making Waves by Imelda Carroll is published by Red Books. This is her debut collection and contains 13 stories. Some have been published before but for the majority it will be their first time in print. Imelda takes her inspiration from the sea and the poignancy of the human condition. The book will be launched by bestselling author, Martina Murphy.
The Wexford Bohemian Issue #5 Launch
7.30 p.m. Red Books
The Wexford Bohemian is a literary journal based in Wexford. Founded at Red Books, Wexford’s own eccentric independent bookstore, The Wexford Bohemian was inspired by the roots of several Irish anthologies alongside the City Lights Pocket Poets Series. Having published many writers from Wexford and beyond, this edition is dedicated to new writers. There will be an evening of dynamic performances, discussion of Wexford’s history and a celebration of this county’s rich literary talent. Edited by Álanna Hammel, this issue predominantly features young people who will be published for the first time, including several members of Red Books’ own Wexford Youth Literary Society.
Brian Brody and The Ghost Ensemble
8 p.m. Wexford Arts Centre
Brian Brody and the Ghost Ensemble is a collaboration between singer-songwriter Brian Brody and composer Simon Quigley. They create and perform songs of love, loss and hope, shaped around Brody’s big baritone voice, creating a dynamic akin to Scott Walker and Elvis Costello’s ‘Juliette Letters’ with the Brodsky quartet. Together, they have performed Scott 4, Scott Walker’s seminal album and this, in part, has carved out their sound. For this performance at the Wexford Arts Centre expect an eclectic mix of original music, sung by Brian Brody, accompanied by Simon Quigley on piano, a full string section and other interesting instrumentation, as well as dramatic songs that offer hints of Brel and Walker.
October 23-30
Singing-Swinging Pubs
9 p.m.-10.45 p.m.
The Guinness Wexford Singing and Swinging Pubs competition returns this year after a short sabbatical, perhaps the oldest amateur talent competition in Ireland, stretching back to the 1950s. It’s not just the singing, there is plenty of musical swinging, and it will take place over eight nights, starting at 9 p.m. with the last act at 10.45 p.m. The format is simple: three pubs a night, from October 23 to 30, will host a show before a packed audience and an adjudicator. This year 23 pubs are participating, bookended by Maggie Mays (Oct 23, 9 p.m.) and the Talbot Hotel (Oct 30, 10 p.m.) Admission is free: you can find the full programme on the event’s Facebook page. The thousands of people who have contributed and competed in the Guinness Wexford Singing and Singing Pubs competition have managed to nurture the event through time. They have also worked hard to ensure the original competitiveness and atmosphere, having started out in 1952, still exists today.
October 24-25
S.P.C.A. Art
9 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Wexford Cafes
For over a hundred and fifty years the Wexford Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has promoted the need for animal welfare and the responsible care and ownership of all animals. The charity has launched an innovative fund raising appeal by displaying works of donated art, which are for sale, on the walls of various cafes and restaurants throughout the town, including the Red Kettle, Trimmer’s Lane Café, Charred and 10 Bistro West.
Tuesday October 24
Jazz at The Library
1 p.m. Wexford Library
Jazz on an autumn day at Wexford Town Library will celebrate the opening of the Wexford Festival Opera later that night. This lunchtime concert is an opportunity to see jazz singer Sharon Clancy after her success as a headliner at the Aberjazz International Festival in the UK. With the excellent Terry Byrne on keyboards/piano, Sharon can sing straight-ahead jazz with aplomb and yet switch styles in the blink of an eye. She treats her voice as an instrument with an exceptional gift for phrasing. A frequent headliner over the years at Jazz at Johnstown with the Chris Colloton Trio, Sharon has both a smouldering and sensuous vocal with a seasoned performer’s mastery of the stage. This concert is free but tickets must be booked.
Gianni Schicchi by Giacomo Puccini
The Grain Store at Stonebridge, 5.30 p.m.
The Donati family are mourning the death of their patriarch, Buoso who they believe has left them a vast fortune. Their tears, however, are insincere and when they learn that Buoso has in fact left all his money to a monastery, they become frantic with greed. Buoso’s duplicitous heirs connive to change the will. Rinuccio, who wishes to marry Lauretta, (Gianni Schicchi’s daughter), suggests that the wily Schicchi will have a solution to the family’s dilemma. Schicchi’s plan is to rewrite the will in the family’s favour. Since no one outside the family knows that Buoso is dead, Schicchi will pose as Buoso, change the will and then ‘die.’ The family manages to hoodwink both the doctor and the notary into thinking that Schicchi is Buoso, only to be outwitted at the last by Schicchi who double crosses them and takes the inheritance for himself. Sung in English. A walk through production. Community Opera Sponsor: Energia Group.
Opera Festival Fireworks
Wexford Quay, 7.15pm
The 2023 Wexford Festival Opera is to be officially opened by An Taoiseach Leo Varadkar at 7.15 p.m. The traditional fireworks display will follow at 7.30 p.m. over the harbour. The programme for the 72nd festival centres around the theme of Women and War, with each chosen work highlighting a different aspect of the struggles women face; in conflict, fighting prejudice and in making their voices heard. The programme will comprise of three main stage opera rarities, two pocket operas, the Wexford Factory opera, 11 lunchtime recitals, an immersive community opera, a choral recital with New Dublin Voices, the annual gala concert of festival favourites, film screenings, the Dr Tom Walsh lecture given by Lara Marlowe, and a myriad of free pop-up events all around the town. The three main stage operas are a modern premiere of Zoraida di Granata by G. Donizetti 1822 in co-production with the Donizetti Festival in Bergamo, the French rarity L’Aube rouge by Camille Erlanger 1911, and La Ciociara 2015, in a new orchestration for Wexford Festival Opera by original composer Marco Tutino.
Zoraida di Granata by Gaetano Donizetti
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 8 p.m.
A modern premiere, Zoraida di Granata follows the experience of a woman drawn into war against her will, in a battle to save her love. The action takes place during a Spanish attack on the Moorish capital of Granada, where King Almuzir is in love with Zoraida, the daughter of the king he has deposed and whose throne he has usurped. But she is already betrothed to his general Abenamet. Machinations ensue, and though Almuzir tries to dispose of Abenamet, the general outwits the ruler by disguising himself as an unknown knight. Abenamet finally wins the day by forcing the king into a remorseful confession, even defending the usurper against the people’s wrath. A happy end sees Zoraida and Abenamet reunited. Sung in Italian with English surtitles. Production sponsored by Elavon.
Wednesday October 25
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
As you walk the streets of Wexford, you might come across people dancing. Or you might walk into a store and hear singing. Have they gone crazy? No, it’s just one of our Pop-Up events. Introduced into the Festival programme two years ago, the success is such that we advise you to grab one of our maps and go to the venues in advance so as not to miss a single note. You will not be disappointed! Locations and times of Pop-Up events are available on wexfordopera.com
Wexford Festival Tours
Wexford Festival Tours are organised by Bernard Browne on behalf of Wexford Historical Society. The Festival Tours, which have been running since the first Festival, are led by expert guides who take you to interesting and intriguing places throughout Wexford town and county, some known, some lesser-known. All tours meet at the hotel at 10.30 a.m. sharp. If you don’t have a car, don’t worry as people with cars make room for those without. Don’t miss this opportunity to explore Co. Wexford’s ‘Hidden Gems’ and make new friends.10.30 am
La Fille du regiment opéra-comique by Gaetano Donizetti
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 11 a.m.
Brought up as the ‘daughter’ of a French Regiment during the conflict between France and Austria, Marie has been told by her ‘father’ Sulpice that she must marry a soldier, but Marie has fallen for an Austrian, Tonio. Unexpectedly caught up in the war, the Marquise de Berkenfield and her attendant Hortensius meet the regiment. Sulpice makes a connection between the Marquise and papers discovered with the foundling Marie. The Marquise says that she is Marie’s aunt and wants to take Marie away from the regiment and from Tonio, who has joined the army to marry her. Sung in French with English dialogue.
Lunchtime Recital
St Iberius Church, 1 p.m.
Audiences can appreciate the musical versatility of solo singers who perform a wide variety of music from across the repertoire, including operatic arias, lieder, oratorio, concert and popular songs. Please note this lineup is subject to change and names of artists may change.
Wednesday, October 25
Suor Angelica by Giacomo Puccini
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 3.30 p.m.
The opera opens in a convent where the nuns are going about their daily lives. They talk about their desires. Sister Genevieve admits that she would like to see lambs again having been a shepherdess and Sister Dolcina longs for tasty food. Sister Angelica claims to have no wishes, but the other nuns believe that Sister Angelica has lied. They know her true hope is to hear from her family who she has not had contact with in 7 years. The nuns have heard rumours that Sister Angelica was banished to the convent as punishment. Their conversation is interrupted by the news that a magnificent coach is waiting outside. Sister Angelica is agitated, rightly assuming that her family has come to visit her. The Abbess announces the arrival of Sister Angelica’s aunt, the Princess. The Princess tells Angelica that she must renounce her claim to her inheritance as her sister is to be married. Angelica replies that she has repented of her sin, but she cannot forget her illegitimate child, who was taken from her 7 years ago. Without compassion, the Princess tells Angelica that her son is dead and Sister Angelica, devastated, signs away her inheritance. Heartbroken Sister Angelica decides to end her life, in the hope that she may at least be reunited with her child in death. She realises that by taking her own life she has committed mortal sin and is damned to be eternally separated from her child. She begs the Virgin Mary for mercy, and, as she dies she sees her child with the Virgin Mary, her son runs to embrace her, and they are finally together. Sung in Italian.
L’Aube rouge by Camille Erlanger
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 8 p.m.
October 26-30
Antique Fair
Talbot Hotel. 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.
The annual Wexford Opera Festival Antiques Fair is one of the highlights of the festival when dealers from all over Ireland have on offer a huge range of displays from military ephemera to postcards and furniture to vintage art.
Thursday October 26
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
Film – Two Women (LA Ciociara)
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 11 a.m.
A war drama movie by Vittorio De Sica
Two Women (the film) tells the story of a young widow, Cesira (Sophia Loren) and her 12-year-old daughter who flee war-ravaged Rome to Cesira’s native village in Ciociaria. Yet, as the allied forces push back the German occupation, the two women fall victim to a devastatingly brutal act at the very hand of the country’s liberators. Free (book tickets in advance). 16+.
Lunchtime Recitals
St Iberius Church 1 p.m.
La Fille du regiment opéra-comique by Gaetano Donizetti
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 3.30 pm
Jessica Traynor Reading
7 p.m. Wexford Library
Jessica Traynor is a poet, essayist, librettist, and poetry editor at Banshee. Her debut collection, Liffey Swim (Dedalus Press, 2014), was shortlisted for the Strong/Shine Award. The Quick (Dedalus Press, 2018) was an Irish Times book of the year. Pit Lullabies (Bloodaxe, 2022) is a Poetry Book Society Recommendation and was an Irish Times book of the year, and a Guardian Best Summer Read of 2022. It was shortlisted for the Yeats Society Sligo/ Irish Independent Poetry Prize. She is 2023 recipient of the Lawrence O’Shaughnessy Award for Poetry. Other awards include the Ireland Chair of Poetry Prize, the Listowel Poetry Prize, and Hennessy New Writer of the Year. She is a Creative Fellow of UCD, and 2023 Arts Council Writer in Residence in Galway University. She is a judge for the 2023 Forward Prizes and a poetry critic for The Irish Times.
La Ciociara (Two Women) by Marco Tutino
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 8 p.m.
The opera opens in Rome in the middle of World War Two. Widowed shopkeeper Cesira shuts up her shop and then is forced against her will to sleep with Giovanni, a dealer in black market goods. In exchange he will give Cesira passage for her and her daughter Rosetta to Ciociara, the mountain village of Cesira’s youth. However, the decision only plunges the two women’s lives further into war’s criminally abusive ways, their dignity as women stripped from them by war’s weapon of rape. In Ciociara, Cesira encounters townspeople suffering their own wartime privations, and is befriended by the bookish pacifist Michele, who becomes her lover. Giovanni, who is collaborating with the Nazis, pursues her to Ciociara, and a rape occurs when Cesira and Rosetta fall into the hands of marauding Moroccan troops. Rosetta, hardened by the assault, breaks with her mother, but the death of Michele signals a reconciliation — and the presumption of healing — for mother and daughter. Sung in Italian with English surtitles. Production sponsored by Danone.
Friday October 27
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
Suor Angelica by Giacomo Puccini
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 11 a.m.
Lunchtime Recitals
St Iberius Church, 1 p.m.
Wexford Literary Trail with Maura Bell
2 p.m. Clayton Whites Hotel
For many visitors, Wexford is an interesting, multifaceted destination, renowned for its excellence in the arts and its immersion in history. It also boasts a plethora of contemporary. writers, celebrated both at home and abroad. In fact, no county in Ireland or indeed a region of its size in Britain can boast as many Booker-nominated writers in the 21 st century. Claire Keegan (short-listed in 2022), John Banville (winner in 2005) and Colm Tóibín, one of the most nominated writers in the history of the award (four times). Pick up your free copy of the new Wexford Literary Trail at Wexford Arts Centre, the National Opera House or White’s Hotel and discover on this hour long tour with Maura Bell how the town and harbour has inspired some of the most celebrated writers in the English language today.
Gianni Schicchi by Giacomo Puccini
The Grain Store at Stonebridge, 5.30 p,m,
Zoraida di Granata by Gaetano Donizetti
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 8 p.m.
Saturday October 28
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
L’italiana in Alegri by Gioachino Rossini
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 11 a.m.
Mustafà, the Bey of Algiers, has become dissatisfied with his wife Elvira and decides to marry her off to Lindoro, his Italian slave. However, Lindoro’s true love is Isabella, who he has left behind in Italy. Unbeknownst to Lindoro, Isabella is on her way to Algiers when her ship is caught in the storm and they are forced to land. Isabella is delighted to see Lindoro, but finds him being held captive by Mustafà who in turn becomes infatuated with Isabella. However, Isabella is more than a match for Mustafà and he falls completely under her spell. She soon manipulates him into believing that he has her heart. By getting the guards drunk and charming the sailors, Isabella and Lindoro escape back to Italy. Mustafà realises he has been hoodwinked and promises to remain faithful to his wife in future. Sung in Italian with English surtitles. Wexford Factory sponsored by PwC.
Lunchtime Recitals
St Iberius Church, 1 p.m.
La Fille du regiment opéra comique by Gaetano Donizetti
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 3.30 p.m.
Film – Two Women (La Ciociara)
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 5.30 p.m.
October 28-30
Hallowe’en at Hook Lighthouse
5.30 p.m. to 7 p.m.
Special ghastly lantern-lead Halloween tours only for those who like the ghoulish and ‘sphooky’ will be on offer at 5.30pm, 6pm, 6.30pm, and 7pm. Venture into darkness as you ascend the 115 steps of the lighthouse, one of the world’s oldest, and amid the graveyard of 1,000 ships, explore the original keepers’ quarters and learn about the ghostly tales behind the Lighthouse and its grounds including the paranormal experiences of previous guests and staff, but not for the faint-hearted.
La Ciociara (Two Women)
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 8 p.m.
Sunday October 29
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
Suor Angelica by Giacomo Puccini
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 11 a.m.
Lunchtime Recitals
O’Reilly Theatre, 1pm
L’Aube rouge by Camille Erlanger
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 5pm
Gala Concert
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 9 p.m.
Presented by Rosetta Cucchi & Marty Whelan The Gala Concert is one of the highlights of Wexford Festival Opera and features a collection of favourite party pieces from members of the Festival Company. All performers generously donate their time and talent for the Gala Concert, and all proceeds go toward supporting Wexford Festival Opera. Kindly supported by Volvo -Bolands Wexford.
October 29-30
Festival Racing Day/Bettyville Park
Bettyville Park offers a festival atmosphere at a day at the races at one of the finest tracks in the country. Wexford has a rich racing culture that continues to flourish; a wonderful mixture of sporting and social intercourse where the friendship and warmth of welcome transcends all boundaries. The racecourse has been developed in stages and is now one of the finest tracks of its kind in Ireland with the constant support of leading trainers and jockeys, both nationally and internationally.
Monday October 30
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
La Fille du regiment opéra comique by Gaetano Donizetti
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 11am
Lunchtime Recitals
O’Reilly Theatre 1 p.m.
Choral Concert – New Dubin Voices
Rowe Street Church, 3 p.m.
International award-winning New Dublin Voices is a leading Irish chamber choir. Founded by conductor Bernie Sherlock in 2005, from the start the choir has presented concert programmes that are fresh, innovative, and exciting, ranging widely in style and period from the medieval to the contemporary. The ensemble takes special pleasure in exploring the music of living composers and has given numerous Irish and world premieres. The Concert, held in the solemnity of Rowe Street Church, will include Jonathan Dove’s The Passing of the Year and Frank Martin’s Mass for Double Choir.
Gianni Schicchi by Giacomo Puccini
The Grain Store at Stonebridge, 8 p.m.
October 30-November 2
Hits from The Musicals
8.p.m White’s Hotel
Featuring a blend of timeless classics and contemporary gems from the world of musical theatre, this Wexford Light Opera Society show – running over four nights - will feature its renowned chorus as well as a variety of soloists who regularly perform or have performed with the Society over the years. The production team is as follows: Musical Director – David Hayes, Director - Stephen Byrne, and Chorus Mistress - Eithne Corrigan. Hits from The Musicals is one of the highlights of the festival events: Master of Ceremonies is legendary singer and actress Catherine “Biddy” Walsh.
Tuesday October 31
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
October 31-November 3
Nutty Scientists Camp
10 a.m, to 1 p.m. St Joseph’s Community Centre
Get ready for a spook-tacular scientific adventure this Hallowe’en! Introducing Nutty Scientists Spooky Science Hallowe’en Camp for a week filled with eerie experiments and creepy discoveries that will leave your young scientists amazed! Camp is suitable for ages 5-12 years, so bring your little mad scientists along for a ghoulishly good time!
Tuesday October 31
Impossible interview
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 11 am
British nurse, statistician, and social reformer who was the foundational philosopher of modern nursing, Florence Nightingale, spent hours in the wards tending to wounded soldiers. Her nightly rounds established her image as the Lady with the Lamp. Hosting another impossible interview, Michael Dervan chats with the woman whose efforts formalised nursing education and the establishment of the first scientifically based nursing school opening in London in 1860.
Lunchtime Recitals
St Iberius Church, 1 p.m.
Suor Angelica by Giacomo Puccini
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 3 p.m.
Zoraida di Granata by Gaetano Donizetti
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House 8 p.m.
October 31-November 1
A Night Of Comedy
8 p.m. Wexford Arts Centre
The Ballycogley Players, All Ireland Confined Drama Festival Winners 2018, present a night of comedy, with two one act plays and comedy sketches. Founded in 1974, Ballycogley Players Drama Group is a close-knit ensemble located in South Wexford, with over 40 members in the group rangingfrom the age of 17 to 75. Synopsis on A Bit of Land by Agnes Adams: Farmer Tommy Boyle, thinking his father Andy has died, persuades his friend Dan Murphy to impersonate the dead man for the purpose of making out a will. Synopsis on Peas by David Tristram: Gerry and Daisy are the first to test out a new dating agency. They soon discover just how much they have in common.
Wednesday November 1
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
Suor Angelica by Giacomo Puccini
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 11 a.m.
Lunchtime Recitals
O’Reilly Theatre, 1 p.m.
La Fille du regiment opéra comique by Gaetano Donizetti
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 3.30 p.m.
Turn Turn
7 p.m. Presentation Centre, Enniscorthy
Anita Mahon is an Enniscorthy based musician, musical director, vocal and piano tutor and performance coach. She has worked on many large-scale vocal projects with children and adults of all ages and was founding musical director and conductor of the Munster Rugby Supporters Club Choir. She currently conducts Enniscorthy Gospel Choir and Yellow Bellows, Music Generation Wexford’s teenage singing group. Over the last number of years Anita has been committed to the exploration and development of her composition and songwriting skills and she was allowed to work with amazing local artists and bring to life one of her compositions, Turn Turn.
L’Aube rouge by Camille Erlanger
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 8 p.m.
Thursday, November 2
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
Suor Angelica by Giacomo Puccini
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House. 11 am
Lunchtime recitals
St Iberius Church, 1 pm
Free Range Poetry
1 p.m. Wexford Library
Members of The Purple and Gold Writers Collective will host a series of dynamic poetic performances in Wexford Library starting today. This series aims to promote poetry as a whole along with promoting a selection of poetic works available at Wexford library. Performances will be followed by a Q&A; session from the audience. Open to anyone who would like to begin their writing journey, or are interested in flourishing their career as a writer.
L’italiana in Alegri by Gioachino Rossini
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 3 pm
Film – Two Women (La Ciociara)
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 3.30 p.m.
Under Milk Wood
7 p.m. Wexford Library
‘To begin at the beginning: It is spring, moonless night in the small town, starless and bible-
black.’
November marks the 70th anniversary of Dylan Thomas’s masterpiece Under Milk Wood and 2023 also marks the 70th anniversary of the poet’s untimely death. It is believed that the first Irish production of Under Milk Wood was performed by an acting society belonging to a university in Dublin at the Wexford Festival in the mid-1950s. For this reading of the play in its entirety, actor Dylan Jones as the First Voice will introduce you to the dream world of Llareggub, a topsy-turvy Welsh village by the sea, populated by a huge cast of characters performed by a stellar cast of Sharon Clancy, Michael Dunbar, Jackie Hayden, and, returning from London for the performance, Teresa Boyle.
La Ciociara (Two Women) by Marco Tutino
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 8 p.m.
The Picture House presents:
8.30 p.m. Jerome Hynes Theatre
The Picture House (Wexford Film Society) kicks off its 2023/24 season with a special screening at the Jerome Hynes Theatre. You Resemble Me is a French film directed by Dina Amer. Cultural and intergenerational trauma erupts in this story about two sisters on the outskirts of Paris. After the siblings are torn apart, the eldest, Hasna, struggles to find her identity in this multi-award-winning film that examines the roots of radicalization.
Friday, November 3
Pop-Up Events
Various Locations
Dr Tom Walsh Lecture: From Innocent Victims to Daring Warriors; Real-Life Stories of Women in War
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 11 a.m.
The 2023 Dr Tom Walsh Lecture will be given by Lara Marlowe. Lara Marlowe has been a journalist for more than forty years and witnessed firsthand the impact of war on women. At Wexford Festival Opera, she will recount how the loss of loved ones, rape, bombardment, and exile transformed the lives of women she met. And she will describe the women participating in the defence of Ukraine.
Lunchtime Recitals
O’Reilly Theatre, 1 p.m.
Listening Workshop
2 p.m. to 3 p.m.
Join writer Alison Ní Mháirtín for a Listening Party Workshop to celebrate the launch of the third story in her ‘Scéalta Draíochta’ audio story series for children and their adults. The workshop will be in Irish and English. Set in Redmond Park, Iníon Phuimcín (the Pumpkin’s Daughter) is a mystery that follows lead character Gínie on a bewitching Hallowe’en tale. As well as listening to the story, all workshop participants will have the chance to make their spooktacular story map. Each story in the Scéalta Draíochta series is broadcast on RTÉjr Radio and is accompanied by an ‘easy reader’ booklet with text as Gaeilge, in English and phonetics, which will be given to participants on the day. No prior knowledge of the Irish language is required.
Oscar Wilde for Children
2 p.m. Johnstown castle
Oscar Wilde wrote some of the most memorable short stories for children, revealing his breath-taking dexterity in a wide range of literary styles, and both The Happy Prince and The Selfish Giant, interpreted brilliantly by actor John Aspinall, conveys the brilliance of his vision, his empathy and a stunning juxtaposition of wit and sentiment.
Marina Carr in Conversation
3. p.m. Green Acres Gallery
The return of the Festival Forum features a question-and-answer session with Marina Carr is one of the most distinguished Irish playwrights of her generation. Author of over 30 plays, Marina is celebrated for writing tense and dark plays and for her range of female characters, united in their struggle against the limited role ascribed to them as women. In many of her plays, such as Hecuba, Marina has explored what a woman’s life lived through war or violence was like, what she might have suffered and to have her children sacrificed.
Oscar Wilde Walk
Noon. Johnstown Castle
Relive the genius and wit of one of Ireland’s greatest writers, Oscar Wilde, whose connections with Wexford are many, with a walk (duration 50 mins) around Johnstown Castle estate, in which actor John Aspill will recite excerpts from some of his greatest works, including The Picture of Dorian Gray, The Ballad of Reading Gaol, Salome and poems such as Ravenna and Magdalen Walks.
La Fille du regiment opéra comique by Gaetano Donizetti
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 3.30 pm
Gianni Schicchi by Giacomo Puccini
The Grain Store at Stonebridge, 5.30 p.m.
Masquerade Ball
7.45 p.m. Talbot Hotel
Organized by Wexford’s Able-Disabled Club, this event includes a champagne reception and four four-course meals with music by Wrecking Ball. Mask is included with the ticket for this black-tie evening.
Anne Gildea
8 p.m. Wexford Arts Centre
Anne Gildea is waxing her mustache, slathering on the Oestrogel, and boiling with excitement about returning to Wexford with her fabulous hit show! It’s been packing in hot women – and interested fellas – all over Ireland since its sell-out launch last year. Now you have another chance to join Anne on this hilarious, informative rollercoaster through all things menopause and womanly. Why is so little known about this inevitable phase of lady--- life? What is it? Why does it happen? Is there anything you can do about it?
Zoraida di Granata by Gaetano Donizetti
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 8 p.m.
November 3-5
Big Ron Betts
Casey’s Wygram: Time Varies
Winner of the 2021 Orange Blossom Blues Challenge for Solo performance. Blues guitarist and singer Big Ron Betts is Wexford bound, traveling over from the USA to play some intimate dates at this new hostelry, Casey’s of Wexford. He lists his influences as BB King, Jimi Hendrix, Stevie Ray Vaughn, Eric Clapton, Buddy Guy and Muddy Waters. Big Ron performs on Friday, November 3rd (6 p.m.), Saturday, November 4th (4 p.m.) and Sunday, November 5th (2 p.m.)

La Fille du regiment opéra comique by Gaetano Donizetti
Jerome Hynes Theatre, National Opera House, 3.30 p.m.
Teddy’s Haunted House
Noon. Wexford Arts Centre
Sammy Ragdoll and her best friend Eddy the Teddy find themselves staying overnight away from home. Of course, around Halloween it easy to let your imagination run away with you, especially if you are a timid Teddy Bear. Eddy is convinced that the house is haunted. Sammy goes off to investigate a noise and prove Eddy wrong. However, that leaves him alone, or is he? The show is designed for children under six and their families. The only one likely to be scared is Eddy the Teddy. It uses many elements of theatre, mime, puppetry, and songs to join in. It a perfect introduction to live entertainment for children who’ve never been to a show before and a welcome return for Eddy the Teddy& young fans. A Barking Dog Theatre Company production.
Gianni Schicchi by Giacomo Puccini
The Grain Store at Stonebridge, 5 p.m.
L’Aube rouge
O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 8 p.m.
Mark Redmond and Chris Colloton Trio play The Táin
8 p.m. Johnstown Castle
One of the musical highlights of the Festival this year. Jazz at Johnstown again brings together jazz and Irish trad to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the seminal Horslips album, The Táin, with a few additions from other sources such as The Book of Invasions. Wexford
Piper Mark Redmond will join Jazz at Johnstown frequent headliners, the Chris Colloton Trio. The coming together of these great musicians will demonstrate how both trad and jazz can easily incorporate aspects of each other into a stunning fusion of improvisational brilliance. Mark has toured globally as a soloist and ensemble musician. This is a one-off occasion to see these four eminent musicians playing a classic from the Irish repertoire as an ensemble. (Supported by the Night Time Economy Unit in the Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media.)
The Lost Brothers
8 p.m. Wexford Arts Centre
The Lost Brothers is a collaboration between two songwriters; Oisín Leech from Meath and Mark McCausland from Tyrone. Their sound is inspired by a range of influences including Patrick Kavanagh and John Fante, the music of Billie Holliday, and the paintings of Jack B Yeats. The Guardian described their most recent album, ‘After The Fire After The Rain’, as ‘sublime’ while The Irish Times stated that the album was ‘deeply soulful’. BBC 6 Music got behind the album with Iggy Pop and Steve Lamacq playing the songs. BBC 6 also awarded it ‘Album Of The Day’. The release was their sixth to date. The album was also shortlisted for the Northern Ireland Music Prize and an ‘Album Of The Week’ at RTE Radio 1. In 2021 the band headlined Union Chapel London and sold-out the prestigious Vicar Street in Dublin.
Sunday November 5

O’Reilly Theatre, National Opera House, 11 a.m.
Wexford Book Fair
11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Talbot Hotel
The Wexford Book and Collectors’ Fair at the Talbot Hotel this year celebrates the 52nd anniversary of Ireland’s longest-running book fair. As always there will be thousands of well- priced books including rare editions, first editions, ordinary editions, and signed editions.

Spiegeltent Festival
Wexford’s Spiegeltent Festival is set to return for its 11th year from October 20 to November 5 promising to bring even more glamour, fun and enchanting experiences on Wexford’s quay front.
Set in the beautiful surroundings of the original Fortuna Spiegeltent, a lovingly handcrafted venue designed and built by Flemish Craftsmen in the early 20s, Wexford Spiegeltent Festival has an air of olde worlde mystery that blends seamlessly with the best in modern entertainment. It is a truly unique experience, and since 2012 has grown to be one of the biggest and most successful multi-genre festivals in Ireland.
For tickets, see wexfordspiegeltent.com
October 20: Jenny Greene.
The DJ will kick off the festival on its opening night. Jenny Greene has been at the forefront of the Irish Dance music scene for almost 20 years. Jenny’s Spiegeltent show sold out in just five minutes and due to popular demand a second date was added for November 3.
October 21: Al Porter.
The comedian will be taking to the Spiegeltent stage. After six years away, Al steps back into the spotlight with his most personal show to date, an upfront and upbeat take on his journey to here.
October 21: Green Road.
The Wexford folk/ballad band combine the lively sounds of 5-string and tenor banjos, flat picked guitar, mandolin, uilleann pipes and whistles, bass guitar and vocal harmonies. Green Road have forged a unique sound that will have you singing along from start to finish.
October 22: Keith Barry.
The internationally acclaimed Mind Magician will be taking to the stage to blow the minds of festival goers. His mind-blowing skills have been showcased in over forty international television shows, including most recently ‘Hypnotize Me’ which aired on the CW network in the US -based on the smash ITV hit ‘You’re Back in The Room’, ‘Hypnotize Me’ went down a storm with the American audience – as well as RTÉ series ‘The Keith Barry Experience’.
October 25: John Bishop.
The comedian is set to take to the stage for two sells out shows on October 25. The comedian is finding his feet again. It’s a landscape in which he has reached the top and achieved more than he ever thought was possible but rather than resting on his laurels he decided to go back to the small comedy clubs of New York to rediscover the thrill of trying to win over an audience who had no idea who he was. He will be returning to the festival after his first stint in 2019.
October 26: The Hold My Drink Podcast.
Charleen Murphy and Ellie Kelly present Hold My Drink, a GoLoud Original podcast. Think of the girl’s bathroom on a night out, or the group chat the next morning. That is the vibe of the podcast. The two social media stars spill all the gossip on life, relationships, love, breakups and much more.
October 26: The Prohibition Party.
Ireland’s King of Swing Luke Thomas and his band The Swing Cats will play the Prohibition Party. They will be performing a very special Prohibition Edition of their hit show The Story of Swing featuring all your favourite SWING and Big Band classics. Come as a flapper girl, come as you are, come as a dapper gent, or a silent screen star … either way come ready to party like it’s 1929!
October 27 & 28: The Coronas.
One of Ireland’s biggest and most loved bands, The Corona’s will do two nights in Wexford Spiegeltent Festival on Friday 27 and Saturday 28 of October. The Coronas have been making waves in the music scene since their debut album Heroes or Ghosts, with numerous multi-platinum albums, chart-topping singles, and sold-out arenas to their name.
October 29: Mick Flannery.
The singer is one of Ireland’s most acclaimed songwriters and performers. The award-winning, double platinum selling artist has released seven studio albums, three of which have reached No. 1 status.
October 30: The Whistlin Donkeys.
The Whistlin Donkeys are the gift that keeps on giving, following a SOLD-OUT Park live show in August they’re coming back to Wexford Spiegeltent Festival in October 29th, 2023.
November 1: OTT Wrestling.
Catch characters performing breath-taking acrobatic moves, battling out good versus evil. Cheer the lucky underdog, the sore loser, the strong unstoppable heroes through title bouts, challenges, and defences. Follow the feuds, grudges, love triangles, and above all, the improvised comedy that only Over the Top Wrestling provides.
November 1 & 2: The Waterboys.
The popular reach of Waterboys music has never been greater. Their songs have been performed by artists as varied as Prince, The Killers and U2.
November 3: The Academic.
Following their much talked about and spectacular performance at Electric Picnic 2023, The Academic have just announced a run of Irish dates which includes a one-night stand at Wexford Spiegeltent Festival.
November 4: Neil Delamere.
Internationally acclaimed and award-winning comedian Neil Delamere returns this Autumn with a brand-new show, Neil by Mouth.
November 5: Kristian Grey Magician.
Step into a world of whimsey and wonder as internationally renowned magician, Kristian Grey, takes centre stage in his ALL NEW, uproarious comedy magic show for kids! Prepare to be spellbound by Kristian’s enchanting blend of mind-boggling illusions, hilarious antics, and dazzling trickery.
WEXFORD ART TRAIL
WEXFORD TOWN:
Irish Gothic at Wexford Co. Council
Wexford County Council and Wexford Arts Centre in partnership with the Irish Museum of Modern Art present Irish Gothic by artist Patricia Hurl, whose work by its nature is political, traversing the disciplines of painting, multi-media and collaborative art practice. In Patricia’s early work the faces are obscured and the paint applied with an urgency that hints at the emotion felt by a woman living in a male-dominated society. (Monday to Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.)
The Pigyard Gallery
In this exhibition, Tom King captures the rich, varied and distinctive landscape around Ireland’s coastline in both oils and watercolours. From bogs to beaches, mountains, marshes and pastures together with the omnipresent influence of the Irish sky on the landscape, all come under the gaze of the artist’s brush, painted directly from the subject in his free-flowing spontaneous style. (Monday to Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.)
Westgate Heritage Centre
A collection of work by contemporary Wexford artists including Mick Mulcahy, Liam O’Rourke, Ann Maria Bridges, Paddy Lennon, Serena Caulfield, Caroline Ward, Milena Minta Barnes and many more. (Opening from October 26, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. daily).
Green Acres Gallery
The featured artist at the annual Green Acres Gallery Wexford Festival show is sculptor Colm Brennan. Also participating in the extensive group show are the following artists: Neisha Allen, Margo Banks, Cheryl Brown, Ken Browne, Aidan Butler, Marian Campbell, Tom Climent, Joe Dunne, James English, Martin Gale, Cara Gordon, Ann Hearne, Myra Jago, Taffina Flood, Stephen Johnston, Robert Kelly, Bernadette Madden, Helen O’Connell, Mary O’Connor, Gwen O’Dowd, Padraig Parle, Trish Robinson, Fergus Ryan, Robert Ryan, Neil Shawcross RHA, RUA, John Noel Smith, Blaise Smith RHA, Donald Teskey, Conor Walton. Alison Kay, John Behan, Sandra Bell, Roger Bennett, Valentin Boston, Anna Campbell, Eamonn Ceannt, Dawn Conn, Orla de Bri, Ray Delaney, Ana Duncan, Michael Foley, Stephanie Hess, Rachel Joynt, Stephen Lawlor, Elizabeth Petcu, Bob Quinn, Anthony Scott RUA, Joseph Sloan, and Tea Svaric. (Monday to Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.)
Wexford Arts Centre
Wexford Arts Centre and Wexford County Council Arts Department in partnership with South East Technological University present LOOP by Emma Roche, recipient of the 2021 EMERGENCE Visual Art Award. Emma’s works shift between the figurative and abstract, combining the methodologies of knitting with paint to create layered and textured works. Emma lives and works in Wexford and is a 2023 Artist in Residence at the Sam and Adele Golden Foundation, New York. Curated by Catherine Bowe. (Tuesday to Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.)
Wexford Wildfowl Reserve
Wexford wildlife painter Dave Daly is celebrating 25 years of his annual exhibition of vivid paintings from nature at the Pumphouse, and will feature a selection of work from various locations over the past two decades right up to both his time at Stanley Park in Vancouver in Canada earlier this year and new works painted in his Co Wexford studio. (Monday to Saturday, noon. to 5 p.m.)
Wexford Library: Transpose
Mary O’Connor is an artist who makes paintings, screen prints and large-scale murals using bold abstract geometric designs and a strong colour palette. Born in Wexford, Mary now lives in Dublin. She studied at TU Dublin, Chelsea College of Art in London, and in New Zealand. Mary had a solo exhibition at SO Fine Art Editions in 2020 and has exhibited regularly in group exhibitions including the Royal Academy London, RHA Annual Exhibition in Dublin, RUA Annual Exhibition in Belfast. (Monday to Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m./ late night opening on Tuesday and Thursday.)
Creative Hub.
A magnet for visitors to Wex-Art is the Creative Hub which hosts working studios and galleries including Bernadette Doolan, Nadia Corridan, Ciaran Bowen and Oonagh Latchford, the Printmakers Studio (Deirdre Meehan-Buttimer), the Wexford Arts Hub Collective and the Art in Progress group show. (Opening: times vary so please consult with artists before visiting.)
Deirdre Meehan-Buttimer uses everyday objects to draw, print ‘mark make’ and collage on a range of surfaces with striking effect. Her collage landscapes, on linen effect paper, collaged from subconscious monotype prints with Ogham ‘stone graffiti’ like writing, resonate with an ancient, Neolithic Ireland. (Opening: Oct 27th
– Oct 30 th , 3 p.m. to 6.30 p.m; Nov 2, 5 p.m. to 8.00 p.m. and Nov 3 to Nov 5, 3 p.m. to
5.30 p.m.)
Art in Progress: curated by Anya von Gosseln. The annual show of superlative contemporary work from near and far this year features Anne Martin Walsh, Mary Ruth Walsh, Liam Ryan, Ita Grattan, Stephen Nolan, Patrick Redmond, Ciaduio Negosanu, Les Levine, Daniel Tuomey lamp after Eileen Grey, Lawrence Weiner, Martin Mullen and James Mathers.
National Opera House: Women and War
In addition to their art practices, the artists presented in this exhibition, curated by Catherine Marshall, are further connected through their associations with County Wexford, their responses to adversity and their independent approach to the daily challenges in modern life. (Monday to Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.)
Diana Chambers, now working out of the KCAT studios at Callan, but a former resident at Camphill in Duffcarrig in North Wexford, is a painter of extraordinary spontaneity and power. Her work has been shown in many group exhibitions, including the Engagement Project, 2014–2021. Lorna Corrigan, another KCAT artist who lived for many years in Duffcarrig, near Gorey is a painter of a very different kind. Inspired by a visit to Australia, her very colourful work is influenced by Aboriginal art. Helen Comerford studied art in Northern Ireland and Holland before coming to live for years in Garrylough Mill. She is best known for her abstract, encaustic paintings but she has always worked with three-dimensional form, even in her paintings. Alanna O’Kelly, brought up and now living in County Wexford, is one of Ireland’s leading performance and installation artists. Her socially-engaged practice has led her to work with new communities to Ireland while her personal exploration of the Great Famine in Ireland prioritises the link between that history and global hunger. Gerda Teljeur came to Ireland from Amsterdam in the 1960s and now lives and works near Wexford town. Her practice involves time and a slow build-up of marks and materials to express abstract emotions, mental and physical states and the relationship between mankind and the earth.
Also on show on various floors throughout the National Opera House is individual work by Serena Caulfield, Ann Maria Bridges, Bernadette Doolan, Caroline Ward and Paddy Lennon and Nadia Corridan.
Pop Up Exhibitions:
Rosemary Clancy unveils her latest work, oil on canvas, which are an extraordinary distillation of colour and subject, at the National Opera House café; view the stunning work at Barker’s of Helen Mason whose impressionistic and almost mystical landscapes are iconic, known for their ability to capture the essence of the haunting landscapes of the Hook Peninsula. Growing up in the village of Slade, Helen was part of a tightly knit fishing community and spent her childhood swimming in the sea and exploring the dramatic coastline around the historic Hook Lighthouse. For over a hundred and fifty years the Wexford Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has promoted the need for animal welfare and the responsible care and ownership of all animals. The charity has launched an innovative fund raising appeal by displaying works of donated art, which are for sale, on the walls of various cafes and restaurants throughout the town, including the Red Kettle, Trimmer’s Lane Café, Charred and 10 Bistro West.
FURTHER AFIELD:
Kelly’s Hotel, Rosslare
A regular at the RHA Annual Exhibition in recent years is still life artist Caroline Ward, for whom still life is an opportunity to appreciate ordinary objects too subtle to merit our attention. Caroline aims to capture calm and serenity in each arrangement, as well as the sense of space within the composition. (Monday to Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.)
The Rosslare Gallery Invited artists each bring their unique interpretation of the theme - Visual Music - to celebrate the wonderful array of music, song and art that is Wexford Festival Opera, including Patrick Cahill, Kate Kos, Paul Maloney, Jane Meyler, Orlagh M. Murphy, Sheila McNally, Tony Robinson, Lori Putnam, Manon West, Ulrich Gleiter and Antonin Passemard. (Monday to Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.)
Johnstown Castle
Imogen Stafford specialises in creating sculptures from mixed media including chicken wire inspired by mythology and Irish wildlife. (Monday to Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.)
Failing Upwards: Presentation Centre, Enniscorthy
From the cutely, nightmarish octopus and ceramic creation, to the dizzying hallway of murals, Gibson has created a brand new world of ghosts, demons, mushrooms and clouds in his highly detailed street art style: inspired by the Renaissance era of cartoon illustration, the characters on display are bold, bright and emotive. (Monday to Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.)
Feeder/Daytime: Blackbird Cultur-Lab
Blackbird Cultur-Lab is hosting FEEDER, an ongoing research library of publications on farming, food production, soil health and sustainability by Deirdre O’Mahony. As this is a working farm, it will be open to the public by appointment only. Feel free to contact Blackbird Cultur-Lab with your enquiries via: https://www.blackbirdcultur-lab.com Big Barn Arts and Antiques Take a trip out of town and visit the wonderful Big Barn Arts and Antiques in Bridgetown, (Y35VH05) to see this solo exhibition by Wexford based artist Trisha O’Callaghan who trained as a printmaker at Limerick School of Art and Design before returning to her native county to take up a role as a secondary school teacher. While her work is multi-disciplinary her main area of practice is painting. (Mon 21st Oct –Fri 3rd Nov 1pm-5pm daily).
